displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So often we think of bone as being, we have this sort of feeling that bone is worse, but mostly because we just have trouble imaging and seeing how it changes. So, uh, but it also affects some of the trials we have because those trials require biopsies of tumor tissue, and it’s really hard to get tumor tissue from the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it may alter what we can do in terms of trials. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So today, I thought we could talk a little bit about kind of what the standard things are to do next, and then we could talk a little bit about some trials that we have. The typical thing we would do next is either to put you on another hormone- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so you’d be on the shot and a pill. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, we talked before about there’s a drug called, Zytiga, and a drug called, Xtandi. Uh, they both could, could work very well, uh, and they’re both associated with improving survival in men who get the drugs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The main side effect of both is fatigue. Patient: Um hum.

Family Member: Oh. Doctor: However you want to bill it and put it in a nice package, anything you take is a potential drug swirling around in your bloodstream. Family Member: Hm Mmm. Doctor: How much, how little, we don’t know. So at the moment, while you’re on other treatment, I wouldn’t advise it. Okay? Family Member: It could nullify the treatment? Doctor: Yeah. Or make it worse. Patient: Well then you mentioned other supplements. Doctor: Right. I think your standard basic multivitamin, it’s a thumbs up. Because that’s just sort of your regular, you know, recommended daily allowance, your recommended daily intake, that’s no problem. But if you start taking high doses of things, we just don’t know what it’s going to do. Family Member: What is that black pill you’re taking? Patient: That’s the macular- Family Member: For macular degeneration? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah! You told me he talked to you. Doctor: I know. Patient: You say. Doctor: So, I said, I know you. That if we did that and everything else, you would just sort of give up. You’d be like, “I’m done. I can just barely -- my quality of life is here.” But I have to tell you, if you really needed it. One, I think your quality of life would actually be much better because you’d be so symptomatic from that problem, you couldn’t ride your bike. You couldn’t go around the block. You couldn’t do anything! You’d just be soiling yourself constantly! So, if that came to be the issue, you would want it done just to improve your quality of life. Patient: Okay. Listen. Doctor: But I also know that that’s not something you would do proactively because the thought of having a bag scares the heck out of you. I know that. I got it. And now I just threw in two possible bags that’s even more frightening. So, I need you to focus on what we have to do next. We gotta get some systemic stuff swirling through your bloodstream – Patient: Okay, but -- Doctor: To get control. We’re fixing it here, but the rest of you is not controlled. Doctor: Okay? Hi!!! Patient: So. So. Doctor: We’re having all sorts of discussion! Healthcare Professional 2: Really?

Family Member: Yeah I thought eliminate something that doesn’t irritate. Doctor: Okay Patient: My D three. All my D three and all my vitamins. Doctor: Oh, yes. Did you feel better? Patient: Everything. Um, well, I’m feeling better now but I think I’m feeling better because my stomach- Doctor: Yeah. Well you’re away now more time away from radiation. Patient: Exactly. Doctor: So you know radiation is tough. It helps the pain but it’s always something for something, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: not something for nothing, so there’s some side effects there. And you got a lot of radiation. Patient: So the question there being then probably safe to go back on the supplements? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: On some of them. I would gradually reintroduce them if I was you.

Family Member: You might not know what’s making you feel – Doctor: Exactly. So I want to just poison you one thing at a time. Family Member: Poison (chuckles) Doctor: Okay? Patient: And the V___ Patient: I was seeing a doctor V___ in O____ in D____. Doctor: That’s him. Patient: That’s him. Doctor: We got him here. Patient: Oh he’s here now. Doctor: He’s here now. So he’s the go-to guy to get that process through. It goes through his group. Okay? So my suggestion is that we just have a discussion with him about side effects and pros and cons and what not as the next step. In the meantime you’re taking more pain medicine, right? Regularly. Family Member: I can’t – he’s like a little child “time for your medicine, are you going to take it?” Doctor: I know.

Patient: I got that did. Doctor: Yep. See slowly we’re fixing you up. Patient: Yeah I’ll be good in no time. Okay. (laughs) Doctor: The only thing not behaving is your prostate number though. Patient: That’s because I didn’t get it. After three months it was four and a half. That’s what happened. Doctor: Yeah. You still shouldn’t be sort of rising. Patient: I shouldn’t go… Doctor: So I think what we’re gonna do because it’s been a while since we checked your bone scan and your CAT scan. Patient: Hmm hmmm. Doctor: Because remember we had those lymph nodes, we tried to get at those lymph nodes and this way we just want to recheck again because your last set of scans was twenty sixteen. So it’s probably a good idea to look Patient: Hmm yeah. Doctor: So W____’s gonna write out the paperwork for the bone scan.

Patient: And occasionally I’ll swing I’ll get a zinger down here and that’s from back there you know. And the neurologist told me to quit playing. Doctor: Yeah I was gonna ask you did you check with the neurosurgeon if it’s safe to do it. Patient: Oh yeah. Nah, it’s not safe. Doctor: It doesn’t sound safe. Patient: No. Doctor: Oh you’re just preferring to not get … Patient: Well I got a… Doctor: But you don’t want to. Patient: I got to address that. I got to address that and… Doctor: All the more reason to do surgery if it holds up your paddleball and all that stuff right? Patient: Well maybe, yeah, right. Family Member: Well what the – will that lesions – his legs are really weak and they hurt. Would that lesion? Patient: It’s not bad is it?

Family Member: And tired. Doctor: Yeah. Especially now, I’m not even doing a thing to poison you, you should feel better. Doctor: Um hum. So is that the highest? Patient: So absolutely. Absolutely. I don’t, I don’t get readings like that. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You know? It can be in the two twenties. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Which is too high. Doctor: Yeah. Less than two hundred would be great. Patient: But, but, uh, you know, but with the pump I give daily bolus myself. Doctor: Yeah. Exactly. Yes. Patient: So, uh, even, even in all the frequent trips have to wake up in the morning and have to urinate, I check my sugar. Doctor: Okay. And? Are you okay at night?

Family Member: So, um, we’ve had a little bit of a (pause) Doctor: So, so, well, here, here’s - I have lack of flexibility. So, again, I can only see you on Tuesdays. Family Member: Got it. Doctor: Okay? So, again, unless we give you the chemo on the same day, but it’s going to be Wednesday or Thursday. Um. And, again, most people are not under the bed. Most, unless you, you are puking your guts out which is pretty rare. Most people are just, sort of, feel like that they’ve, um - “I—I- I gotta go take a nap.” Family Member: Yeah, that’s what T_ said. Doctor: So, I- I--I am just gonna go take a nap. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s not bad. There’s nothing wrong with ya. You know, if you’re achy- Patient: Just tired. Doctor: Just ‘cuz, you know, you’re just take a couple of Advil, and you just say, “I, I gotta go take a nap.” Most people don’t notice much. Uh, just like, “Okay, they told me I’d feel it this weekend.” Uh. Family Member: Okay! Doctor: Most people really just lose the end of their day. You know, they’re at work, work, work, and they just sorta say, “Oh.” And they’re toast. Patient: And when the end of the day is all over, you nap.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And so half the people get it, half the people don’t- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: but you still have to come in and get an infusion three times a week. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And so that one is logistically pretty tough. But that is something that you know if we’re going chemotherapy, I can make sure we get you the permission slip or the consent form to let you know what that would look like. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may, I don’t think we have an opening at Hospital B but that’s one of the sites that we collaborate with, and I think they had interest in opening it, and so we can check in to see whether they have that open. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But that would be clearly if we say I’m doing chemotherapy, do I want to do something more on top of it, so that would be one option. Experimentally we have two treatments, uh one based on the fact that your ARV7 is positive. We have an experimental study where we give everyone immune therapy, a doublet. That is a combination of two drugs that are approved in melanoma, soon to be approved in kidney cancer that can turn on your immune system to attack your cancer. It doesn’t work all that well so far in prostate cancer, maybe fifteen percent of people may get a benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Yeah. It really is sort of out of pocket. Family Member: But he could do it right away? Doctor: He could potentially. I, I, at least I could contact my contact and find out. I also know the group in Heidelberg. We could find out. Uh the groups here, uh I don’t know the Cornell group and the group at UCLA. I don’t know. Those are trials. So they’re going to have eligibility. Patient: Do you think I’d be eligible for them? Doctor: I don’t know. I, I can look into it. Patient: Yeah. I - Doctor: Well, I mean, I don’t know. I can find out from the group at Cornell which sounds like at least would be- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Within striking distance for you from, from the east coast. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: How quickly? If you’re eligible, how quickly you could uh- Patient: Sure. Sure.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So January thirtieth. Family Member: Okay, right. Doctor: So everything else that we’re going to add up now will be related to the study. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Um and yeah, you’ve got the visit with Dr___, and his team – Family Member: Catheter Doctor: - to change the catheter – Patient: Right. Doctor: - but if you don’t need that because you’re doing it locally - Patient: Right.

Patient: Okay, that’s fine… Doctor: ‘Cause I don’t think it’s related… Patient: Right. Doctor: …however all these other doctor’s appointments all gotta go right according to plan… Family Member: Yes. Doctor: …so that we don’t make you worse because there’s still no matter what some clearance of you know, any of the medicines are always somewhat cleared, some percentage by the kidneys so… Patient: Right I understand that. Doctor: …we don’t want to make that worse. Okay. Family Member: Mhmm. Patient: Right. Well we looked up the side effects of uh Doctor: Mhmm. The enzalutamide. Yeah. Patient: …uh the enzulamide, whatever. Um there wasn’t anything in there that indicated a kidney uh… Doctor: Right.

Family Member: Alright. So it is called immunotherapy? Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Um. What’s the difference? There must be different types? Doctor: There’s different types. So this one is very specific to you. That’s why we have to take out cells. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: To give back your better cells. Family Member: Cells. Oh, okay. Doctor: The other immune therapies are more generic. Family Member: Right. Okay. Doctor: So you don’t need specialty whatever. It just knows to try to go to the areas that is deemed cancer. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: So that’s the ones you see on TV now- Doctor: No. This is the only one. Right.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: But we haven’t had a scan since April of last year. So we might as well get one this year. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: See how things are. You know? See how the lymph nodes and bone stuff is doing just to make sure we don’t have to do anything exciting. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You okay with that? So that’s the CAT scan again, there’s the chest, the bone in the pelvis, and then the bone scan, which is basically stuff like that. Just to make sure. Patient: Hum. Hum. Doctor: And we’ll compare it to all the ones before. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: This is not a huge jump. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Nothing that I’m going to freak out about. But we want to be prepared in case it’s starting to wake up. Patient: Hum.
